bibl.title: Letter from Currier McEwen to Philip Showalter Hench, October 10, 1951

div1.p: McEwen comments on Hench's telegram message for the New York University College of Medicine ceremony honoring Walter Reed.

div1.head: Letter from Currier McEwen to Philip Showalter Hench, October 10, 1951
div1.opener:
NEW YORK UNIVERSITY-BELLEVUE MEDICAL CENTER
NEW YORK UNIVERSITY COLLEGE OF MEDICINE
477 FIRST AVENUE, NEW YORK 16, N.Y.
October 10, 1951
OFFICE OF THE DEAN
OREGON 9-3200
Dear Phil:
div1.p:
I'm sorry not to have written long ago in answer
to your nice letter and about the telegram and some of
the points you wanted to know regarding our data on
Walter Reed. The unfortunate fact is that I misplaced
your letter and could not remember the particular points
you inquired about; and I have been hoping ever since
that your letter would turn up. However, the letter hasn'
come to light and I can't wait any longer without letting
you know how very much we appreciated the telegram you sent
us. It really is a gem and I used it as the highlight of
our ceremonies commemorating Walter Reed's birthday. I also
quoted it in my opening address to the Freshman students a
week or so later for I could find no other words quite so
good to use in pointing out to the new students the aims
of medicine. Now your telegram is a part of our material
on Walter Reed in the college library.

The ceremony for Reed went off quite well, I think.
Frank Netter, one of our graduates of a few years ago, was
present as the painter of the portrait of Walter Reed which
the alumni presented to the school. Netter is really a
competent artist and we are glad indeed to have his painting.
General Reed and Mrs. Blossom Reed were not able to come
but we had a goodly representation of others interested in
military medicine and tropical medicine and the like, and I
believe our party was well worth having, In fact, I believe
it would have been well worth while if only to provide an
occasion to read your telegram!

I am sorry I haven't got your questions before me so
that I can answer them. Perhaps you will be good enough to
send them to me again, if you still have them in mind.
My thanks to you and best greetings to you and Mary.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, Currier McEwen, M.D.
Dean Dr. Philip Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
